test_questions.question: What is software according to the provided materials?

options.A: A physical product that wears out over time
options.B: A product created by software engineers that includes programs, data structures, and documents
options.C: Only the executable code that runs on hardware
options.D: A manufacturing product with assembly requirements

test_questions.question: Which statement best describes the nature of software projects?

options.A: Software is manufactured like hardware products
options.B: Software requires physical assembly and production lines
options.D: Software development costs are primarily in manufacturing

test_questions.question: What happens to software over time regarding failures?

options.A: It wears out physically like hardware
options.B: The failure rate decreases as it becomes more stable
options.C: The failure rate increases with changes and modifications
options.D: It becomes more reliable without any maintenance

test_questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a software application domain mentioned?

options.A: System Software

test_questions.question: What is the primary characteristic of System Software?

options.A: Stand-alone programs for specific business needs
options.C: Resides within products/systems to control features
options.D: Includes operating systems, device drivers, and development tools

test_questions.question: Which software domain includes 'number-crunching' programs for fields like astronomy and meteorology?

options.A: System Software

test_questions.question: Where does embedded software reside?

options.A: On web servers in the cloud
options.B: Within products or systems to control features and functions

test_questions.question: What is product-line software?

options.A: Software developed for a single customer
options.B: Reusable components with specific capabilities for different customers

test_questions.question: Which type of software uses heuristics to solve complex problems?

options.A: System Software

test_questions.question: What is described as 'the bedrock that supports software engineering'?

options.A: Process

test_questions.question: In software engineering layers, what does the 'Process' layer do?

options.A: Provides technical how-to's for building software
options.B: Holds the technology layers together and enables rational development

test_questions.question: What do 'Methods' encompass in software engineering layers?

options.A: Only coding and programming techniques
options.B: Communication, requirements analysis, design modeling, and testing

test_questions.question: What does CASE stand for in software engineering tools?

options.A: Computer-Aided Software Engineering

test_questions.question: How is a 'process' defined in software engineering?

options.A: A rigid prescription for how to build computer software
options.B: A collection of activities, actions, and tasks performed to create work products
options.C: Only the coding phase of software development
options.D: The testing methodology used in a project

test_questions.question: What is the difference between an 'activity' and a 'task' in software process?

options.A: An activity is small and well-defined, while a task is broad
options.B: An activity strives for a broad objective, while a task focuses on a small objective
options.C: Activities are only for managers, tasks are for developers
options.D: There is no difference between them

test_questions.question: What is the intent of a software process?

options.A: To create extensive documentation
options.B: To deliver software in a timely manner with sufficient quality
options.C: To eliminate all communication with stakeholders
options.D: To use the most expensive tools available

test_questions.question: What does a process framework establish?

options.A: Detailed coding standards for all projects
options.B: The foundation for a complete software engineering process

test_questions.question: Which of these is NOT one of the five generic framework activities?

options.A: Communication

test_questions.question: What is the purpose of the Communication activity?

options.A: To write code for the software
options.C: To understand stakeholders' objectives and gather requirements

test_questions.question: What does the Planning activity create?

options.A: The actual software code
options.B: A 'map' or software project plan to guide the team

test_questions.question: What is included in a software project plan?

options.A: Only the budget information
options.B: Technical tasks, risks, resources, work products, and schedule
options.C: Only the names of team members

test_questions.question: What is the purpose of Modeling in software engineering?

options.A: To create physical prototypes of hardware
options.B: To understand software requirements and design through models

test_questions.question: Which modeling language is mentioned as an example for creating diagrams?

options.A: HTML

test_questions.question: What does the Construction activity involve?

options.A: Only writing documentation
options.B: Code generation and testing to uncover errors

test_questions.question: What happens during the Deployment activity?

options.A: Software is delivered to the customer for evaluation and feedback

test_questions.question: How are framework activities typically applied in many software projects?

options.A: Only once in a linear sequence
options.C: Only at the beginning of the project
options.D: Only at the end of the project

test_questions.question: What is produced in each iteration of an iterative process?

options.A: Complete documentation only
options.B: A software increment with a subset of features

test_questions.question: What are umbrella activities in software engineering?

options.A: Activities performed only during rainy seasons
options.B: Activities applied throughout a project to manage progress, quality, change, and risk

test_questions.question: Which of the following is an umbrella activity?

options.A: Coding

test_questions.question: What is the purpose of software project tracking and control?

options.A: To assess progress against the project plan and maintain schedule

test_questions.question: What does risk management involve?

options.A: Assessing risks that may affect project outcome or product quality

test_questions.question: What is the purpose of technical reviews?

options.A: To assess work products and remove errors before propagation

test_questions.question: What does software configuration management do?

options.A: Manages the effects of change throughout the software process

test_questions.question: Why might processes differ between projects?

options.A: Because of differences in flow, degree of definition, stakeholder involvement, and team autonomy
options.B: Because all projects are exactly the same
options.C: Because software is always developed the same way

test_questions.question: According to David Hooker's principles, what is the first principle?

options.A: Keep It Simple, Stupid (KISS)
options.B: The Reason It All Exists - software provides value to users

test_questions.question: What does the KISS principle stand for?

options.A: Keep It Simple, Stupid

test_questions.question: What is the main idea behind the KISS principle?

options.A: Make everything as complex as possible
options.B: All design should be as simple as possible, but no simpler
options.C: Always use the most advanced technology

test_questions.question: What does the 'Maintain the Vision' principle emphasize?

options.A: Changing vision frequently based on feedback
options.B: A clear vision is crucial for project success
options.D: Only developers should know the vision

test_questions.question: What does the 'What You Produce, Others Will Consume' principle mean?

options.A: Only think about your own work
options.B: Create specifications, designs, and code with others in mind
options.C: Produce as much code as possible quickly

test_questions.question: What does the 'Be Open to the Future' principle recommend?

options.A: Design systems that limit future flexibility
options.B: Design systems to adapt to change from the start
options.C: Ignore future changes and focus only on current needs

test_questions.question: What is a warning about the 'Be Open to the Future' principle?

options.A: It should never be followed
options.B: Designing for the general problem can require performance compromises
options.C: It always makes software cheaper to develop

test_questions.question: What does the 'Plan Ahead for Reuse' principle focus on?

options.A: Reuse saves time and effort but is challenging
options.C: Reuse is always cheaper than custom development

test_questions.question: What is a warning about reuse mentioned in the materials?

options.A: It always costs 25% to 200% more than creating software for a specific purpose
options.B: It's always cheaper than custom development

test_questions.question: What is the seventh principle according to David Hooker?

options.A: Think!

test_questions.question: What does SDLC stand for?

options.A: Software Design Life Cycle

test_questions.question: What is the purpose of SDLC?

options.A: To provide a structured framework for software development

test_questions.question: How does SDLC help in quality assurance?

options.A: Ensures software meets customer expectations and standards
options.C: Focuses only on speed of development

test_questions.question: What is the main benefit of SDLC for project management?

options.A: Provides a roadmap for planning, scheduling, and tracking
options.B: Eliminates the need for project managers

test_questions.question: How does SDLC help in risk management?

options.A: Identifies potential risks early in development
options.C: Only identifies risks at the end

test_questions.question: What are the two main types of SDLC models mentioned?

options.A: Fast and Slow models

test_questions.question: What are characteristics of traditional SDLC models?

options.A: Linear and sequential phases with emphasis on documentation
options.B: Flexible and adaptive with minimal documentation

test_questions.question: Which of these is a traditional SDLC model?

options.A: Scrum

test_questions.question: What is the Waterfall Model?

options.A: An iterative and incremental model
options.B: A linear and sequential model where each phase must complete before the next begins
options.C: A model with continuous feedback loops

test_questions.question: What is the first phase in the Waterfall Model?

options.A: Implementation

test_questions.question: Which phase comes after System Design in Waterfall?

options.A: Requirement Analysis

test_questions.question: What is an advantage of the Waterfall Model?

options.A: High flexibility to accommodate changes
options.B: Easy to understand and manage due to linear nature

test_questions.question: What is a disadvantage of the Waterfall Model?

options.A: Too flexible
options.B: Difficult to accommodate changes once project is underway

test_questions.question: When does testing occur in the Waterfall Model?

options.A: Continuously throughout the project

test_questions.question: What is the V-Model?

options.A: An extension of Waterfall that emphasizes verification and validation
options.B: A completely different model from Waterfall

test_questions.question: What is emphasized in the V-Model?

options.A: Testing early in the development process

test_questions.question: What is a disadvantage of the V-Model?

options.A: Too much flexibility

test_questions.question: What is the Iterative Model?

options.A: A model that develops software through repeated cycles and smaller portions
options.D: A model that delivers everything at once

test_questions.question: What is the first step in the Iterative Model?

options.A: Final deployment

test_questions.question: What is an advantage of the Iterative Model?

options.A: Flexibility to adapt to changes

test_questions.question: What is a disadvantage of the Iterative Model?

options.A: Too simple
options.B: Can be resource-intensive due to repeated cycles

test_questions.question: What are Agile methodologies based on?

options.A: Rigid, fixed plans
options.B: Iterative development where requirements evolve through collaboration

test_questions.question: What is one of the Agile Manifesto principles?

options.A: Processes and tools over individuals and interactions
options.B: Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
options.D: Following a plan over responding to change

test_questions.question: What is another Agile Manifesto principle?

options.A: Contract negotiation over customer collaboration

test_questions.question: What are characteristics of Agile development?

options.A: Iterative and incremental development with high customer involvement
options.B: Linear development with no customer involvement

test_questions.question: Which of these is an Agile framework?

options.A: Waterfall

test_questions.question: What is Scrum?

options.A: A traditional linear model
options.B: An Agile framework for managing complex projects with short iterations

test_questions.question: What are the roles in Scrum?

options.A: Project Manager, Developer, Tester
options.B: Product Owner, Scrum Master, Development Team

test_questions.question: What does the Product Owner do in Scrum?

options.A: Writes code for the project
options.B: Represents end-users' interests and prioritizes features

test_questions.question: What does the Scrum Master do?

options.A: Facilitates the Scrum process and ensures team follows Agile practices
options.B: Owns the product and sets priorities

test_questions.question: What does the Development Team do in Scrum?

options.A: Only writes documentation
options.B: Self-organizes to accomplish work planned for each Sprint

test_questions.question: What is a Sprint in Scrum?

options.A: A long development phase lasting 6 months
options.B: A time-boxed period (typically 2-4 weeks) for focused work

test_questions.question: What is the Product Backlog?

options.A: A list of completed features
options.B: A list of prioritized features desired by the customer

test_questions.question: What is the Sprint Backlog?

options.A: All features ever requested
options.B: Selected items from product backlog to be completed in the sprint

test_questions.question: What is a Daily Scrum?

options.A: A 15-minute team meeting to review progress

test_questions.question: What is a Sprint Review?

options.A: Demonstration of new functionality at sprint end

test_questions.question: What tools might be used for Project Management in Scrum?

options.A: Trello or Jira

test_questions.question: What version control system is mentioned for Scrum projects?

options.A: Git and GitHub

test_questions.question: What communication tools are suggested for Scrum teams?

options.A: Slack or Microsoft Teams

test_questions.question: What happens during Sprint Planning?

options.A: Team selects items from Product Backlog for the sprint
options.C: Product Owner writes all the code

test_questions.question: What are the three questions typically asked in Daily Stand-up meetings?

options.A: What did I do yesterday? What will I do today? Any blockers?
options.B: What's for lunch? When is vacation? Who's the manager?
options.C: What's the budget? What's the deadline? Who's the customer?
options.D: How much code? How many bugs? What's the salary?

test_questions.question: What is the purpose of a Sprint Review?

options.A: Demonstrate completed features to stakeholders

test_questions.question: What is a Sprint Retrospective?

options.A: Meeting to reflect on sprint and improve processes

test_questions.question: What is discussed in a Sprint Retrospective?

options.A: What went well, what didn't, and how to improve

test_questions.question: What is an advantage of using Scrum?

options.A: Team can adapt to changes based on user feedback

test_questions.question: What is another advantage of Scrum?

options.A: Stakeholders have visibility into progress during reviews
options.C: All work is hidden until the end

test_questions.question: What is Kanban?

options.A: A linear development methodology
options.B: An Agile methodology focusing on visualizing workflow and limiting work in progress

test_questions.question: What are key concepts of Kanban?

options.A: Visual Kanban Board, WIP Limits, Continuous Delivery
options.B: Long development cycles, No visualization, Unlimited work

test_questions.question: What is a Kanban Board used for?

options.A: Visualizing workflow with columns and task cards

test_questions.question: What does WIP stand for in Kanban?

options.A: Work-In-Progress

test_questions.question: Why are WIP limits important in Kanban?

options.A: They encourage finishing ongoing tasks before starting new ones
options.C: They prevent any work from being done

test_questions.question: What are the key principles of Extreme Programming (XP)?

options.A: Communication, Simplicity, Feedback, Courage, Respect

test_questions.question: What does the 'Simplicity' principle in XP mean?

options.A: Develop the simplest solution that works
options.B: Make everything as complex as possible
options.D: Use the most advanced technology always

test_questions.question: What does the 'Feedback' principle in XP emphasize?

options.A: Obtain rapid feedback from system, team, and customer
options.C: Only get feedback at project end

test_questions.question: What is a benefit of Extreme Programming?

options.A: High-quality software through testing and refactoring

test_questions.question: What is another benefit of XP?

options.A: Flexibility to adapt to changing customer needs

test_questions.question: What is Test-Driven Development (TDD) in XP?

options.A: Write tests after coding is complete
options.B: Write automated tests before writing the code

test_questions.question: What is Pair Programming in XP?

options.A: Two developers work together at one workstation

test_questions.question: What is Continuous Integration in XP?

options.A: Integrate code changes frequently into main branch
options.B: Integrate code only at project end

test_questions.question: What is Refactoring in XP?

options.A: Continuously improve codebase without changing external behavior

test_questions.question: What are Small Releases in XP?

options.A: Deliver software in small, frequent iterations
options.B: Deliver everything at once at the end

test_questions.question: What is an On-site Customer in XP?

options.A: Customer available full-time to provide immediate feedback

test_questions.question: What is Collective Code Ownership in XP?

options.A: Any team member can improve any part of the code
options.B: Only one person can touch the code

test_questions.question: What are the phases in Agile development?

options.A: Concept, Inception, Construction, Release, Maintenance, Retirement

test_questions.question: What is an advantage of Agile methodologies?

options.A: Customer satisfaction through frequent delivery

test_questions.question: What is another advantage of Agile?

options.A: Flexibility to adapt to changing requirements

test_questions.question: What is a disadvantage of Agile?

options.A: Less predictability in final outcomes

test_questions.question: What is another disadvantage of Agile?

options.A: Requires experienced team members

test_questions.question: What is Scope Creep risk in Agile?

options.A: Continuous changes may lead to uncontrolled scope expansion

test_questions.question: How does Traditional development differ from Agile in structure?

options.A: Traditional: Linear; Agile: Iterative

test_questions.question: How does customer involvement differ between Traditional and Agile?

options.A: Traditional: Limited; Agile: Continuous

test_questions.question: How does documentation differ between Traditional and Agile?

options.A: Traditional: Extensive; Agile: Minimal necessary

test_questions.question: What is a case study comparison between Waterfall and Agile?

options.A: Waterfall: Late discovery of issues; Agile: Improved user satisfaction
options.B: Waterfall: Early discovery; Agile: Late discovery
options.D: Waterfall: No testing; Agile: All testing

test_questions.question: When choosing an SDLC model, what should be considered for project complexity?

options.A: High complexity may benefit from Agile's flexibility
options.C: Always use Waterfall for complex projects
options.D: Always use Agile for simple projects

test_questions.question: What should be considered regarding customer requirements when choosing a model?

options.A: Well-defined: Traditional; Evolving: Agile

test_questions.question: What should be considered regarding team expertise?

options.A: Experienced teams can handle Agile effectively
options.B: Only inexperienced teams should use Agile
options.D: Always use Traditional regardless of expertise

test_questions.question: What should be considered regarding time to market?

options.A: Short timelines favor Agile for quicker delivery
options.D: Always take as long as possible

test_questions.question: What factors influence model selection?

options.A: Project size, risk assessment, regulatory compliance

test_questions.question: What is a best practice when selecting an SDLC model?

options.A: Assess project requirements thoroughly

test_questions.question: What is another best practice?

options.A: Engage stakeholders early

test_questions.question: What is DevOps?

options.A: A framework integrating development and operations using Agile principles

test_questions.question: What are key stages of DevOps?

options.A: Continuous Development, Testing, Integration, Deployment, Monitoring

test_questions.question: What is Continuous Development in DevOps?

options.A: Deliverables broken into sprints, each delivered to QA

test_questions.question: What is Continuous Testing in DevOps?

options.A: Automated testing of multiple code increments simultaneously
options.C: Only manual testing at project end

test_questions.question: What is Continuous Integration in DevOps?

options.A: New functionality added to existing codebase and runtime environment

test_questions.question: What is Continuous Deployment in DevOps?

options.A: Tested software deployed to production environments

test_questions.question: What is Continuous Monitoring in DevOps?

options.A: Operations teams monitor software performance post-deployment

test_questions.question: What are benefits of DevOps?

options.A: Faster responses to customer demands, enhanced brand loyalty
options.D: Only benefits for developers, not operations

test_questions.question: What is similar between DevOps and other Agile frameworks?

options.A: Collaboration focus and incremental delivery

test_questions.question: How is DevOps different from other Agile frameworks?

options.A: Includes both development and operations, not just development

test_questions.question: What is a good scenario for using DevOps?

options.A: Projects with frequent updates like e-commerce sites
options.B: Small static websites with no changes

test_questions.question: What is a bad scenario for using DevOps?

options.A: Small projects or startups with limited resources

test_questions.question: What tools are used for Planning in DevOps?

options.A: Jira, Trello

test_questions.question: What tools are used for Development in DevOps?

options.A: Git, GitHub, GitLab

test_questions.question: What tools are used for Build in DevOps?

options.A: Maven, Gradle

test_questions.question: What tools are used for Testing in DevOps?

options.A: Selenium, JUnit, Postman

test_questions.question: What tools are used for Integration in DevOps?

options.A: Jenkins, CircleCI

test_questions.question: What tools are used for Deployment in DevOps?

options.A: Docker, Kubernetes, AWS

test_questions.question: What tools are used for Monitoring in DevOps?

options.A: Nagios, Prometheus, New Relic

test_questions.question: What is a pro of Scrum methodology?

options.A: Product owner defines priorities, team makes independent decisions
options.B: No priorities defined, team has no autonomy

test_questions.question: What is a con of Scrum?

options.A: Challenging to manage cost changes, unsuitable for large teams

test_questions.question: What is a pro of XP?

options.A: Focuses on customer involvement, creates rational schedules

test_questions.question: What is a con of XP?

options.A: Risk of shipping incomplete prototypes, frequent costly meetings
options.B: No risks, all meetings are free

test_questions.question: What is a pro of Kanban?

options.A: Lower cost and time needs, enables early delivery
options.B: Higher cost and longer time, delays delivery

test_questions.question: What is a con of Kanban?

options.A: Depends on collaboration, weak analysis harms projects
options.B: No collaboration needed, strong analysis always

test_questions.question: What is a pro of DevOps?

options.A: Speeds deployment, integrates developers and operations
options.B: Slows deployment, separates developers and operations

test_questions.question: What is a con of DevOps?

options.A: Dual code focus adds pressure, heavily relies on automation
options.B: No automation needed, single focus only

test_questions.question: How do XP practices of refactoring and pair programming contribute?

options.A: Improve code quality and team collaboration
options.B: Decrease code quality and isolate team members
options.C: Only speed up development without quality

test_questions.question: What are key differences between Kanban and Scrum?

options.A: Kanban: continuous flow, no fixed sprints; Scrum: time-boxed sprints
options.B: Kanban: fixed sprints; Scrum: continuous flow
options.D: Kanban: only for managers; Scrum: only for developers

test_questions.question: When would Kanban be more suitable than Scrum?

options.A: For support teams with unpredictable tasks
options.B: For projects with fixed, rigid deadlines only
options.C: For large projects requiring many roles
options.D: For projects with no visualization needs

test_questions.question: Can geographical separation in agile teams be an advantage?

options.A: Yes, with proper tools and practices for communication
options.D: Only if all members are in same timezone

test_questions.question: What tools can facilitate communication in geographically separated teams?

options.A: Slack, Zoom, Microsoft Teams, GitHub

test_questions.question: What is a Generic Process Model?

options.A: Encompasses framework activities: communication, planning, modeling, construction, deployment
options.B: A specific model for only one type of project

test_questions.question: What does process flow describe?

options.A: How framework activities are organized with respect to sequence and time

test_questions.question: What is a linear process flow?

options.A: Executes framework activities in sequence (like Waterfall)

test_questions.question: What is an iterative process flow?

options.A: Repeats one or more activities before proceeding to next

test_questions.question: What is an evolutionary process flow?

options.A: Executes activities in circular manner, each circuit leads to more complete software

test_questions.question: What is a parallel process flow?

options.A: Executes one or more activities in parallel with others
options.C: Only one activity at a time

test_questions.question: Example of linear process flow project?

options.A: Developing a university student portal

test_questions.question: Example of iterative process flow project?

options.A: Developing a fitness tracking app

test_questions.question: Example of evolutionary process flow project?

options.A: Developing an AI-powered chatbot

test_questions.question: Example of parallel process flow project?

options.A: Building large-scale healthcare management system

test_questions.question: What influences what actions are appropriate for a framework activity?

options.A: Nature of problem, characteristics of people, stakeholders

test_questions.question: For a small project, communication might involve:

options.A: Just a phone call or email with stakeholder

test_questions.question: For a complex project, communication might include how many actions?

options.A: Six actions: inception, elicitation, elaboration, negotiation, specification, validation

test_questions.question: What is a task set?

options.A: Defines actual work to accomplish objectives of a software engineering action

test_questions.question: Example task set for requirements gathering in small project?

options.A: Make stakeholder list, invite to meeting, discuss requirements, prioritize
options.B: Write all code first, then gather requirements
options.D: Only interview each stakeholder separately with formal techniques

test_questions.question: What does a software process NOT guarantee?

options.A: Timely delivery, meeting customer needs, long-term quality

test_questions.question: What must a software process be coupled with?

options.A: Solid software engineering practices (CMMI, ISO 9001)

test_questions.question: What are Prescriptive Process Models sometimes called?

options.A: Traditional process models

test_questions.question: What do Prescriptive Process Models define?

options.A: Structured steps and predictable workflows

test_questions.question: What is a challenge of Prescriptive Models?

options.A: Less suited for rapidly changing requirements

test_questions.question: What is a limitation of the Waterfall Model?

options.A: Real projects rarely follow sequential workflow it proposes

test_questions.question: What is another limitation of Waterfall?

options.A: Customer must state all requirements explicitly at beginning

test_questions.question: When is prototyping ideal?

options.A: When requirements are unclear or incomplete

test_questions.question: What does the prototyping model allow?

options.A: Developers and stakeholders to refine software through iterative feedback

test_questions.question: What is Quick Design in prototyping?

options.A: Simple, preliminary design focusing on visible aspects like UI

test_questions.question: What is the Evolutionary Process Model also known as?

options.A: Spiral Model

test_questions.question: What does the Evolutionary Model emphasize?

options.A: Incremental development through iterative cycles

test_questions.question: What is suitable for Evolutionary Model?

options.A: Projects with evolving requirements or tight deadlines

test_questions.question: Key distinction of Evolutionary Model from Prototyping?

options.A: Explicitly integrates risk analysis in each iteration

test_questions.question: Example of Evolutionary Model use?

options.A: Space mission control system with risk analysis

test_questions.question: Example of Prototyping Model use?

options.A: Mobile app startup focusing on UI/UX refinement

test_questions.question: What does Unified Process (UP) combine?

options.A: Elements of traditional models with agile principles

test_questions.question: What does UP focus on?

options.A: Iterative and incremental development, architectural planning

test_questions.question: What modeling language does UP use?

options.A: UML (Unified Modeling Language)

test_questions.question: What are phases of UP?

options.A: Inception, Elaboration, Construction, Transition, Production

test_questions.question: What happens in Inception phase?

options.A: Define basic requirements, identify risks, create preliminary plan

test_questions.question: What happens in Elaboration phase?

options.A: Refine requirements, establish architectural baseline

test_questions.question: What happens in Construction phase?

options.A: Develop and integrate components for current increment

test_questions.question: How does UP differ from Evolutionary Model in iteration?

options.A: UP: structured phases with overlapping activities; Evolutionary: continuous iterations
options.B: UP: no iteration; Evolutionary: structured phases
options.D: UP: only one iteration; Evolutionary: many phases

test_questions.question: How does UP use UML compared to Evolutionary Model?

options.A: UP relies heavily on UML; Evolutionary does not emphasize UML
options.B: UP never uses UML; Evolutionary uses UML heavily

test_questions.question: What is architectural focus difference between UP and Evolutionary?

options.A: UP establishes strong architectural baseline early; Evolutionary evolves architecture incrementally
options.B: UP has no architecture; Evolutionary has fixed architecture
options.D: UP ignores architecture; Evolutionary focuses only on architecture

test_questions.question: How do UP and Evolutionary differ in risk management?

options.A: UP identifies risks early in inception/elaboration; Evolutionary incorporates risk analysis in each iteration
options.B: UP never manages risks; Evolutionary only at end
options.C: Both manage risks the same way
options.D: UP only during construction; Evolutionary only during planning

test_questions.question: Example of UP project?

options.A: Healthcare management system with defined phases

test_questions.question: Example of Evolutionary project?

options.A: Fitness tracking app with basic features then advanced
options.B: University student portal with all features upfront
options.C: Legacy system replacement with fixed requirements
options.D: Document management system with no changes

test_questions.question: What is a pro of Waterfall model?

options.A: Easy to understand and plan, works for well-understood small projects

test_questions.question: What is a con of Waterfall?

options.A: Does not accommodate change well, testing occurs late

test_questions.question: What is a pro of Prototyping?

options.A: Reduced impact of requirement changes, customer involved early
options.C: Work never lost, easy to plan

test_questions.question: What is a con of Prototyping?

options.A: Customer involvement may cause delays, temptation to 'ship' prototype
options.C: Too easy to plan and manage

test_questions.question: What is a pro of Spiral model?

options.A: Continuous customer involvement, development risks managed

test_questions.question: What is a con of Spiral model?

options.A: Risk analysis failures can doom project, requires expert team
options.B: No risk analysis needed, any team can use

test_questions.question: What is a pro of Unified Process?

options.A: Quality documentation emphasized, continuous customer involvement

test_questions.question: What is a con of Unified Process?

options.A: Use cases not always precise, tricky software increment integration
options.B: Use cases always perfect, integration easy

test_questions.question: What is Process and Product Duality?

options.A: Both interdependent: weak process leads to poor product

test_questions.question: How do different process flows address project challenges?

options.A: Linear for stable requirements, iterative for evolving, evolutionary for continuous feedback
options.B: All work the same for any project
options.C: Only linear works for all projects
options.D: Only evolutionary works for all projects

test_questions.question: How to resolve conflicting requirements from multiple stakeholders?

options.A: Use prototyping to demonstrate options, gather feedback, refine based on agreement

test_questions.question: Example of conflicting requirements resolution?

options.A: Fitness app: manual vs automatic tracking demonstrated via prototype

test_questions.question: What are advantages of combining process models?

options.A: Balances structured planning with adaptability

test_questions.question: What are disadvantages of combining process models?

options.A: Increases complexity in management and coordination

test_questions.question: Example of combined process models?

options.A: Waterfall for initial planning and Spiral for iterative risk handling in healthcare

test_questions.question: What is the Recommended Process Model perspective on linear models?

options.A: Risky to use without ample feedback
options.C: Only linear models should be used

test_questions.question: Is upfront requirements gathering always possible or desirable?

options.A: Never possible nor desirable to plan big upfront requirements gathering

test_questions.question: May upfront requirements gathering reduce costs or prevent time slippage?

options.A: May not reduce costs or prevent time slippage
options.B: Always reduces costs and prevents slippage

test_questions.question: What is integral to software development according to Recommended Process Model?

options.A: Appropriate project management

test_questions.question: How should documents evolve with software?

options.A: Documents should evolve with software and not delay construction
options.B: Documents should be created only at end
options.D: Documents should be created before any work

test_questions.question: When should stakeholders be involved?

options.A: Early and frequently in development process

test_questions.question: When should testers become involved?

options.A: Prior to software construction

test_questions.question: What are benefits of Incremental Models over linear models?

options.A: Better for evolving requirements, early customer feedback

test_questions.question: What are challenges with Incremental Models?

options.A: Risk of throwaway prototypes, stakeholders may push excessive changes

test_questions.question: How should prototypes be designed to minimize wasted effort?

options.A: With reuse in mind
